reinforcement.notes: Young (1975) states that every scoring rule satisfies reinforcement (also called 'consistency'). Anti-plurality is a scoring rule; hence it satisfies reinforcement.

condorcet_winner.notes: Schulze (2011, Table 2) notes that Baldwin is a Condorcet method.

independence_of_clones.notes: Laffond et al. (1996, Proposition 8) prove that the Banks set is composition-consistent, which implies independence of clones (Berker et al. 2025).

condorcet_winner.notes: Schulze (2011, Sect. 4.7) proves that Beat Path satisfies the Condorcet criterion (as a special case of the Smith criterion).

monotonicity.notes: Schulze (2011, Sect. 4.5) proves that Beat Path satisfies monotonicity.

neutral_reversal.notes: Here we are assuming the margin-based version of Beat Path, and all margin-based methods satisfy neutral reversal.

pareto_dominance.notes: Schulze (2011, Sect. 4.3) proves that Beat Path satisfies the Pareto criterion.

smith.notes: Schulze (2011, Sect. 4.7) proves that Beat Path satisfies the Smith criterion.

monotonicity.notes: Felsenthal (2012, Table 3.3) states that Black satisfies monotonicity.

condorcet_loser.notes: Felsenthal (2012, Table 3.2) states that Borda does not elect Condorcet losers.

monotonicity.notes: Felsenthal (2012, Table 3.2) states that Borda satisfies monotonicity.

neutral_reversal.notes: Saari (2003) notes that Borda satisfies neutral reversal.

pareto_dominance.notes: Felsenthal (2012, Table 3.2) states that Borda satisfies Pareto dominance.

reinforcement.notes: Young (1975) states that every scoring rule satisfies reinforcement (also called 'consistency'). Borda is a scoring rule; hence it satisfies reinforcement.

weak_positive_responsiveness.notes: Holliday and Pacuit (2025) note that all proper scoring rules (in the sense of Zwicker 2016, Def. 2.9) satisfy weak positive responsiveness. As a positional scoring rule, this covers the method.

monotonicity.notes: Felsenthal (2012, Table 3.2) states that Bucklin satisfies monotonicity.
Felsenthal (2012, Table 3.3) states that Copeland satisfies monotonicity.

positive_involvement.notes: Holliday & Pacuit (2021) state that Instant Runoff (IRV) satisfies positive involvement.

condorcet_winner.notes: Young and Levenglick (1978, p. 287) state that Kemeny's rule satisfies the Condorcet criterion.

monotonicity.notes: Schulze (2011, Table 2) lists Kemeny–Young as satisfying monotonicity.

weak_positive_responsiveness.notes: Holliday and Pacuit (2025, Table 1, Footnote 16) show that Kemeny satisfies weak positive responsiveness.

monotonicity.notes: Schulze (2011, Table 2) states that the Simpson-Kramer method (Minimax) satisfies monotonicity.

neutral_reversal.notes: Here we are assuming the margin-based version of Minimax, and all margin-based methods satisfy neutral reversal.

pareto_dominance.notes: Schulze (2011, Table 2) states that the Simpson-Kramer method (Minimax) satisfies the Pareto criterion.

positive_involvement.notes: Perez (2001) proves that Minimax (Simpson–Kramer) satisfies positive involvement.

weak_positive_responsiveness.notes: Fact 3.1 in Holliday and Pacuit (2025) proves that Minimax satisfies weak positive responsiveness.

condorcet_winner.notes: Niou (1987, p. 193) states that Nanson proved that his voting rule satisfies the Condorcet condition. Also: Niou (1987, p. 193) states that Nanson proved that his voting rule satisfies the Condorcet criterion.

monotonicity.notes: Felsenthal (2012, Table 3.1) states that Plurality satisfies monotonicity.

reinforcement.notes: Young (1975) states that every scoring rule satisfies reinforcement (also called 'consistency'). Plurality is a scoring rule; hence it satisfies reinforcement.
Young (1975) shows that every scoring rule satisfies reinforcement (consistency). Positive–Negative voting is a positional scoring rule, so reinforcement holds.

condorcet_winner.notes: Tideman (1987, p. 186) states that Ranked Pairs satisfies the Condorcet criterion.

monotonicity.notes: Schulze (2011, Table 2) lists Ranked Pairs as satisfying monotonicity.

independence_of_clones.notes: Zavist and Tideman (1989) show that Ranked Pairs ZT satisfies independence of clones.

neutral_reversal.notes: Ranked Pairs is a margin-based method, and all margin-based methods satisfy neutral reversal.

monotonicity.notes: Schulze (2011, Table 2) lists Slater as satisfying monotonicity.
Holliday & Pacuit (2023) prove Split Cycle satisfies non-negative responsiveness (the standard monotonicity criterion; see Proposition 5.43).

negative_involvement.notes: Holliday & Pacuit (2023) prove that Split Cycle satisfies negative involvement.

neutral_reversal.notes: Split Cycle is a margin-based method, and all margin-based methods satisfy neutral reversal.

positive_involvement.notes: Holliday & Pacuit (2023) prove that Split Cycle satisfies positive involvement.
